message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient is experiencing a drug-induced psychosis. Among the options, the most likely primary mechanism responsible for this is inhibition of NMDA receptors. This is commonly seen with the use of dissociative drugs such as phencyclidine (PCP) and ketamine. The reduced degree of facial expression and muscle rigidity are also consistent with NMDA receptor antagonism.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient is experiencing an episode of delirium caused by substance abuse. Among the options, only inhibition of NMDA receptors can cause muscle rigidity, reduced facial expression, and amnesia. Stimulation of cannabinoid receptors can cause hypertension and tachycardia, but not muscle rigidity or reduced facial expression. Stimulation of 5HT2A and dopamine D2 receptors can cause hallucinations and delusions, but not muscle rigidity or reduced facial expression. Inhibition of norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine reuptake is a mechanism commonly used in antidepressant medications, which is not relevant to this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits muscle rigidity, reduced facial expression, and no recollection of the incident. These symptoms are suggestive of NMDA receptor inhibition. None of the other options explain the patient’s symptoms as accurately.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including muscle rigidity and reduced facial expression suggest the patient is experiencing a psychotic episode. Among the options, inhibition of NMDA receptors is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms. This is seen in disorders such as schizophrenia and can be induced by drugs such as phencyclidine (PCP).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms of hallucinations, muscle rigidity, and reduced facial expression, which are consistent with NMDA receptor inhibition. Stimulation of cannabinoid receptors can cause euphoria and altered perception, but not muscle rigidity. Stimulation of 5HT2A and dopamine D2 receptors can cause hallucinations, but not muscle rigidity. Inhibition of norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine reuptake can cause agitation, but not muscle rigidity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest she may be experiencing hallucinations and delusions, which are common symptoms of drug-induced psychosis. Among the options, inhibition of NMDA receptors is the most likely primary mechanism responsible for this patient's symptoms. This is because NMDA receptor antagonists, such as phencyclidine (PCP) and ketamine, are known to induce psychosis-like symptoms, including hallucinations, delusions, and altered perception of reality. Stimulation of cannabinoid receptors and stimulation of 5HT2A and dopamine D2 receptors can cause some symptoms, but not all that the patient is experiencing. Inhibition of norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine reuptake may cause agitation and muscle rigidity, but not hallucinations and delusions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient exhibits symptoms consistent with PCP (phencyclidine) intoxication, which is known to be an NMDA receptor antagonist. This drug can cause hallucinations, delusions, and agitation. A, B, and C do not match the symptoms of PCP intoxication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of agitation, muscle rigidity, reduced facial expression, and memory loss suggest the patient is experiencing delirium, which is a common side effect of NMDA receptor inhibitors. Among the options, only (D) mentions NMDA receptor inhibition. The fact that the patient was smoking a cigarette before the symptoms suggest that the NMDA receptor inhibitor is most likely phencyclidine (PCP), which is known for causing aggressive behavior and memory loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of the patient suggest drug-induced psychosis. Among the options, only inhibition of NMDA receptors can cause similar symptoms. Stimulation of cannabinoid receptors can cause relaxation and euphoria, stimulation of 5HT2A and dopamine D2 receptors can cause hallucinations and psychosis, and inhibition of norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine reuptake can cause agitation and confusion but not muscle rigidity.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has developed acute psychosis, and among the options, only Inhibition of NMDA receptors is associated with acute psychosis. Stimulation of cannabinoid receptors is associated with decreased anxiety and psychomotor agitation. Stimulation of 5HT2A and dopamine D2 receptors is associated with hallucinations and delusions. Inhibition of norepinephrine, serotonin, and dopamine reuptake is associated with increased energy, euphoria, and disinhibition.
